dataIdInfo.idPurp: This is the coherence map for a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The pixel values indicate the magnitude of correlation between the two acquisitions, with a value of 0 indicating complete lack of correlation and a value of 1 indicating perfect correlation. It is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 18N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m. It was processed from the SLC using 20x4 looks (20 looks in the range direction and 4 looks in the azimuth direction).
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This is the coherence map for a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The pixel values indicate the magnitude of correlation between the two acquisitions, with a value of 0 indicating a complete lack of correlation and a value of 1 indicating perfect correlation. It is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 18N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m. It was processed from the SLC using 20x4 looks (20 looks in the range direction and 4 looks in the azimuth direction).

Reference Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20161006T230536_20161006T230606_013376_015576_F8FA

Secondary Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20161123T230536_20161123T230606_014076_016B42_0298

Processing Date/Time: 2021-11-19T03:07:55+00:00

The spectra of the two images used for InSAR must overlap well enough to generate interferometric fringes. Areas without common overlap must be filtered out prior to InSAR generation. The correlation indicates the accuracy of the phase information, or the visibility of fringes. Areas with low correlation will have noisier phase. The magnitude of the correlation is commonly referred to as coherence. The coherence map is output as a GeoTIFF with values ranging from 0 to 1; the larger the number, the higher the coherence (and the better the correlation). The values are generated using a sliding window approach, which integrates surrounding information into the calculation of the pixel value while placing a higher weight on the values near the center of the window to reduce loss of resolution.

The coherence map can sometimes be useful as a change detection tool. Decorrelation is caused by changes in the location and orientation of scatterers on the surface of the earth in the time between image acquisitions, and areas with low coherence generally have undergone some sort of change. By looking for low coherence values, you may be able to identify where changes have occurred on the landscape.

Vegetated areas often display very low coherence from one acquisition to the next, as plants grow and change in structure, and even different wind conditions on the acquisition dates can contribute to decorrelation. High levels of crustal deformation can also result in incoherence, which can cause problems when InSAR is being used to measure deformation. If the coherence is too low, the data will not be used when generating interferograms.

Sensors with longer wavelengths will be more robust to decorrelation, so it may be necessary to use data from an L-band sensor when analyzing cases of extreme deformation or where vegetation significantly impacts coherence at shorter wavelengths.

Refer to ASF's InSAR Product Guide for more information about On Demand InSAR products.

The Sentinel-1A satellite was launched April 3, 2014, and the Sentinel-1B satellite was launched April 25, 2016. The satellites each have a 12-day repeat cycle. More information about the mission is available at https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-1.

Additional information about Sentinel-1 data, imagery, tools and applications is available at https://asf.alaska.edu/data-sets/sar-data-sets/sentinel-1.
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
When using this data as an image in a publication such as journal papers, articles, presentations, posters, and websites, please include the following credit with the image (portions in square brackets are optional):
[InSAR product processed by ]ASF DAAC HyP3 2021[ using GAMMA software]. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2016, processed by ESA.
When using this data in a manuscript and/or crediting datasets used for analysis, an acknowledgement including the software versions may be appropriate:
ASF DAAC HyP3 2021 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.1.1 running GAMMA release 20210701. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2016, processed by ESA.
For more information on citing the dataset, please refer to the README file distributed with this product.

Consts.useLimit: There are no restrictions on the use of this data, but it must be acknowledged or cited as listed in the credits.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: This product was generated by ASF DAAC HyP3 2021 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.1.1 running GAMMA release 20210701.

dataLineage.statement:
The coherence map is generated as part of the phase unwrapping workflow (step 8), using GAMMA's cc_wave program.
The basic steps in InSAR processing are as follows:
*Pre-Processing* 1. Ingest SLC data into GAMMA format 2. Get DEM file covering the area, apply geoid correction and resample/reproject as required 3. Calculate overlapping bursts for input scenes 4. Mosaic swaths and bursts together
*InSAR Processing* 5. Prepare initial look-up table and simulated unwrapped image - Derive lookup table for SLC/MLI co-registration (considering terrain heights) - Simulate unwrapped interferometric phase using DEM height, and deformation rate using orbit state vectors 6. Interferogram creation, matching, refinement - Initial co-registration with look-up table - Iterative co-registration with look-up table - Removal of curved earth and topographic phase 7. Determine a co-registration offset based on the burst overlap (spectral diversity method) - Single iteration co-registration with look-up table 8. Phase unwrapping and coherence map generation 9. Generation of displacement maps from unwrapped differential phase
*Post-Processing* 10. Generation of geocoded GeoTIFF outputs
For a detailed description of InSAR processing using GAMMA software, refer to the readme file included with the product package.
